text: Hi Jack, I'm online now, is now still good for you?
Yep!
Amazing!
So tell me a bit about yourself?

Yeah so I'm 18 and in this weird period we've been put in between college and uni but I've got my firm offer for uni at Exeter to do Computer Science which might be a little weird as this is more about VFX. I decided to go down this route because I wasn't sure if I'd definitely want to do VFX forever as I have barely any experience with it and am aware it's quite a challenging workplace so I didn't really want to go down an apprenticeship route or vfx degree as I figured that would lock me in place while computer science can give me more options down the line. I am more technical than creative I think which also helps but yeah. I'm not entirely sure where I want to go with this to be honest maybe advice on different pathways or anything really. Currently I've been thinking more about potentially getting computer science jobs in general graphics programing maybe for some of the companies like foundry and autodesk that actually create the software that's used in vfx and animation and stuff but yeah that's quite a way away :slightly_smiling_face:
OK great, that's helpful to know
So let me introduce myself...

I work for Pearson, who owns Escape Studios. My role is Head of Student Recruitment for the Escape Courses in VFX, Animation and Games, as well as the courses we run in Business Management, Law, Accounting and Data Science. Before joining Pearson, I worked as a careers advisor in an international school and before that I worked at Newcastle University
So my back ground isn't just in VFX, although, that's the idea behind being a mentor on the Access VFX group
Oh I see that makes sense
The VFX industry requires a lot of people who are technical, not just creative, so taking a computer science degree could definitely result in working in VFX
What is it that makes it appealing to work in the VFX industry? I'm just trying to understand more about your interests

Oh yeah so since I was pretty young I thought I was just going to do computer science and work in a generic decent paid computer science job but then around when I was applying to college I realised that that just sounds pretty boring and it wouldn't really be all that fulfilling so I started looking at other things. Around this time I realised I would typically find myself being more interested in watching behind the scenes things for movies and tv shows (I would be more excited for the behind the scenes of the new game of thrones episodes that the actual episodes) so I looked more into vfx and the industry as a whole and just found it really interesting how it's possible to create all these cool things. Since then I realise I probably should have done more to develop my own skills in it and also it's a little ironic that I'm now turning back to computer science but yeah that's just a long way of saying I find the vfx and computer animation (anything cgi) really fascinating and impressive and am more interested in having a career in something I enjoy and am passionate about than one that may pay a bit better but is just boring
Sorry about these really long answers I ramble quite a lot

OK great, so how much have you looked into the roles in the VFX industry? You mentioned the software companies already and you found Access VFX. Are you creative? Even if its photography or digital art rather than hand drawn things

So I'm aware of quite a few of the roles in the VFX industry, I'm guessing roles like TD's would be more fitting for me but generally the textures/lighting and simulation kind of things interest me as well. I like the idea of 3D modelling and animation although I don't see myself ever doing this because of me not being that artistic. And for the creative stuff as an example at college I do Maths, Computer Science and also a media production vocational course so I've made a couple of short film type products and am currently making a music video for that
But I haven't really done much outside of the media course
Brilliant, that sounds like a great course combination
Have you seen this maps of careers in VFX from screenskills? <https://www.screenskills.com/media/3392/vfx-2020-web.pdf>
I've seen similar things before yeah but not quite like this one, interesting

The descriptions for the technical roles are interesting, because there are lots of skills required, on top of being technical. One key one is team work and then having an understanding of the role of an artist
What I've found from people that I've met and worked with who work in the VFX industry, but aren't artists, is that they really need to understand the role of an artist to do their job
Okay yeah so that's something I should probably start working towards
So being a TD may not require you to be an artist, but the more you understand what its like, how long it takes to do things ect, the more it helps
Have you tried modelling anything in Blender or Maya before?

Not really enough for it to count. I have them both installed and a couple of years ago tried to follow a basic blender tutorial and got stuck and have since then only really used it at a recent uni open day

Yea there are lots of tutorials online for Blender and Maya. At Escape, we've got a free Maya 3D online course, if you'd like something to talk you through it <https://www.pearsoncollegelondon.ac.uk/campaigns/3d-vfx-online-taster-course.html>
Oh cool! Thanks
It takes a while to master Maya, but its the industry standard software, so the more you persevere with it, the more you'll know if this is something you'll enjoy.
One thing that I've found the industry VFX industry really values is being able to re-create something from a photo or reference image, in the software.
That tells them that you have an eye for what looks photo real, which is what VFX artists are trying to create
That gives me something to work on over these next 6 months :slightly_smiling_face:
I was looking at the showreel of one of our alumni (we call them Escapees), he's included the reference footage in some of his shots as an example <https://vimeo.com/315097194>

attachments.title: Animation Reel May 2019 - Harry Pearson
attachments.text:
Hi! I'm Harry and I'm an Animator and graduate of Escape Studios with a degree in Art of Computer Animation.

Add me on LinkedIn!: 

For contact details and more of my work, please visit my website -
attachments.fallback: Vimeo Video: Animation Reel May 2019 - Harry Pearson
attachments.video_html: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/315097194?autoplay=1&app_id=122963" width="400" height="225" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; fullscreen" allowfullscreen title="Animation Reel May 2019 - Harry Pearson"></iframe>

text: He's now working in VR for a company called Factory 42, creating a VR experience for the British History museum for David Attenborough
Oh that's cool

So you're planning to start at Exeter University this September? Perhaps you could look to see if they've got some extra curricular things you can get involved with that can help you keep up the creative work, while on your computer science degree
I think I've seen that they have a media type society that run some newspaper, radio and I think some video production which I'll look into
Are you holding offers from anywhere else? Some places having their technical courses, work on briefs from the creative courses, I think I've seen that at Birmingham City University
Those societies sound great though
I've accepted Exeter as my firm choice now and Loughborough as an insurance but I had offers from Bath, Nottingham and Nottingham Trent
Nottingham Trent had more options that related more to VFX and creative industry things but I generally found their uni and course less impressive than the ones I went for
OK great, yes Exeter has a strong reputation as a university

There lots of creative things going on in Cornwall and the South West in general though. There are quite a lot of indy games companies in Falmouth. The skills in computer science and software for games are similar to VFX

I'll look into that thanks. Something I was planning on doing at Uni is a placement year hopefully in one of the types of companies I've mentioned or anywhere related really. I'm quite interested in potentially going abroad for this if possible but that might be challenging
Yes, work experience is essential
Where in the country are you currently based?
Currently I'm in Hampshire

OK. Its a little tough right now with everyone working from home, but when we're all allowed back out again, I'd suggest seeing if some local companies may have work experience, perhaps video editing, creative companies, games companies. Anything that will help build up your team working skills. The VFX industry love great team players
I see yeah I'll definitely look into that when I can
I was at a great talk by the founder of Bluezoo, an animation studio, who's big top tip to get into the industry was just, don't be a dick. Big great to work with and you'll go far
Hopefully that's something I can do :slightly_smiling_face:

I'm going to have to jump off in a few mins, but would it be helpful to chat again in a month perhaps? We can see how you've got on with learning Maya. Out of interest, has your school set you much work to do right now? What's the life of a year 13 student right now?

No problem and that sounds like a good idea. And yeah with college I've got weekly maths assignments and my computer science lessons are as normal although these are a little weird as the exams are cancelled so it feels a bit pointless as we're not actually working towards anything. My media's a little different as we don't know what's happening with it because of it being a cambridge technicals diploma so it might still be going on so with that we're just going through the coursework as normal just at home. Overall though life as a year 13 student right now is pretty confusing as to what's going on haha
I see, there are lots of unknowns
Yeah definitely
Announcements are coming out every day, so hopefully you'll hear what's being decided soon enough
From what I've seen, Universities and exam boards are working over time to find solutions that give student best chance possible
students*
Sorry, for all my typos!

We know a little bit as of how we'll be getting our grades which I'm not overly concerned about as I should be able to get what I need for University but yeah the Media stuff is a bit more awkward as those types of courses aren't really what people are thinking about and generally with the A levels it's a weird place to be working for what appears to be no reason
Yea its an interesting time. Well if you learn something new in the work school is setting, that's a good thing, even if you don't need it for an exam right now. You may need it later on
Thanks
Yeah that’s true I’m sure it’ll be useful for uni

I was inspired by the story of a colleague of mine who went to Oxford University even though he said he wasn't very bright, in the summer before going to uni he read a lot of the books needed for his degree and is really helped give him a head start
How about we catch up again on Monday 20th April at 4pm? Sounds ages away
Sounds good! I’ll let you know if I can’t
Awesome! Chat to you then :slightly_smiling_face:
Great speak to you then!
